channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Is al Qaeda winning regional battle?
item.description: A terrorism analyst says al-Assad's brutality in Syria has revitalized al Qaeda while the Iraqi PM has marginalized the Sunni minority -- actions that are boosting ISIS.

item.title: What does violence cost Kenya?
item.description: Nima Elbagir explains the economic implications of the escalating violence in Kenya.

item.title: How Iraq became unstable
item.description: P.J. Crowley and Bill Kristol debate underlying mistakes and missteps that led to rise of terrorist group ISIS.

item.title: The threat from ISIS's 'Foreign Legion'
item.description: Abu Usama appears to be in his late 20s. With a neat ginger beard and a rifle slung over his shoulder, he addresses fellow Muslims back in Germany from his new home in northern Syria.

item.title: Who are the real World Cup winners?
item.description: When Maria Elza de Fatima learned the World Cup was coming to Brazil in 2014, she thought the good times were soon to return.

item.title: Fierce battles 65km from Baghdad
item.description: Gun battles erupt in a city just 45 minutes drive from Baghdad as ISIS forces advance on government troops defending Baquba.

item.title: Iraq's bitter dividing lines
item.description: Atika Shubert explains the cultural and political dividing lines that could lead to a fractured Iraq.

item.title: Alleged ISIS executions in Iraq
item.description: ISIS militants are hitting back with new images showing cold-blooded executions, as Arwa Damon reports.

item.title: What can, and should, U.S. do now?
item.description: For better or worse, Iraq and the United States have been attached at the hip for decades.

item.title: ISIS has a weakness
item.description: Last week, Iraq's second-largest city of Mosul fell to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS. In a few hours, the city's security forces had dropped their weapons and uniforms and fled. Since then, the militants introduced a political charter in Mosul and marched south, seizing additional towns en route to the capital, Baghdad.

item.title: Fans recreate van Persie's goal
item.description: Forget planking, it's time to get "Persieing."

item.title: 8 fans living in a van
item.description: World Cup fans are finding unique ways to save money on lodging in Brazil. CNN's Isa Soares reports.

item.title: Even in war, time for football
item.description: iReporter Reynaldo Leal traveled to Syria in 2013, and found that even in conflict, there was still time for football.

item.title: All the goals from all the games
item.description: A look at every goal scored during the 2014 World Cup.

item.title: World Cup: 5 things to watch today
item.description: The last of the teams to play their opening match take the pitch, and Brazil and Mexico meet in a battle of the Group A leaders.

item.title: U.S. captures Benghazi prime suspect
item.description: A suspect in the 2012 attack on the U.S. compound in Libya in which the ambassador was killed will face terrorism-related charges.

item.title: 2013: CNN interviews suspect
item.description: Recently, Arwa Damon returned to Libya and spoke to a Libyan militia leader, who is now charged in the Benghazi attack.

item.title: Hero goalkeeper stops Brazil
item.description: Brazil's World Cup has been a carnival of color -- but this was a monochrome affair in Fortaleza.

item.title: Belgium in thriller comeback
item.description: Just when it looked like the World Cup "dark horses" were about to turn up lame, Belgium turned on the power in the final straight to overcome Algeria 2-1 in Belo Horizonte.

item.title: Russia vs. S. Korea score updates
item.description: Keep up to date with today's big World Cup match.

item.title: Hospital bombed in Sudan
item.description: Two bombs hit a hospital run by Doctors Without Borders in the war-torn South Kordofan region of Sudan on Monday, destroying the emergency room, pharmacy and hospital kitchen. The humanitarian group blames Sudan's army for the attack.

item.title: Deadly Kenya attack 'not al-Shabaab'
item.description: Al-Shabaab, the al Qaeda-linked militant group active in Somalia, is not responsible for a terrorist attack in Kenya's coastal town of Mpeketoni that killed at least 48 people, Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta said Tuesday.

item.title: UK to reopen embassy in Tehran
item.description: UK Foreign Secretary William Hague is to announce plans Tuesday for the United Kingdom to reopen its embassy in Tehran, closed since an attack by protesters in 2011 prompted a dramatic breakdown in relations.

item.title: Muslims killed in Buddhist mob attacks
item.description: At least three people have been killed and 80 injured after Buddhist mobs rampaged through Muslim areas in southwest Sri Lanka, police say.

item.title: Russian TV reporter killed in Ukraine
item.description: A Russian television reporter was killed Tuesday while covering the crisis in Ukraine, according to state-run media.

item.title: Pakistan airstrikes 'kill 25 militants'
item.description: Pakistan continued its crackdown on militants in North Waziristan for a sixth day Tuesday, killing more than 20 Taliban and other fighters with airstrikes, the Pakistani army said.

item.title: Jordanian named human rights chief
item.description: The United Nations has just appointed a new human rights chief -- its first to come from the Arab and Muslim world.

item.title: Sewol crew defend their conduct
item.description: The lawyer for the first mate of the ill-fated Sewol ferry told an emotionally-charged court his client left the sinking ship because he thought the coast guard would be able to rescue the passengers.

item.title: Mummified body found in closet
item.description: A 12-year-old boy exploring an abandoned house found a gruesome surprise in one of the closets. Affiliate WHIO reports.

item.title: Twin tornadoes smash town
item.description: Becky Hauf had always been told her little town of Pilger, Nebraska, would never see a tornado. Too close to the Elkhorn River, the folklore went.

item.title: Facebook forcing you to message
item.description: As expected, Facebook has launched a Snapchat-like mobile app that lets users trade ephemeral photo- and video-based messages that disappear after a few seconds.

item.title: Tracy Morgan's condition upgraded
item.description: Comedian Tracy Morgan, who was badly injured in a collision June 7, has been upgraded from critical to fair condition, his publicist said.

item.title: Michael Schumacher out of coma
item.description: Former F1 driver Michael Schumacher is no longer in a coma and has been released from the hospital to continue rehabilitation after a skiing accident last year, his management said in a statement Monday.

item.title: Oscar team eyes Bergdahl movie
item.description: The Bowe Bergdahl story may be coming to the big screen.

item.title: Paul Simon charges dropped
item.description: Paul Simon and his wife Edie Brickell will not be prosecuted on domestic violence charges filed against the couple after an argument, a court official said Tuesday.

item.title: Who does Pele think will win?
item.description: Brazilian superstars Pele and Neymar answer quickfire questions about the World Cup.

item.title: Brazil 2014: The ones to watch
item.description: The World Cup kicks off June 12 in Brazil and will feature some of the world's best players and most enigmatic characters. Here's a sampling of a few you should keep your eyes on during soccer's biggest tournament.

item.title: Science behind that foot
item.description: Adidas has a new ball for the World Cup that's said to be faster and more accurate. Jim Clancy reports on the "Brazuca."

item.title: See Brazil's football shrine
item.description: CNN's Shasta Darlington looks back at the history of Brazil's iconic Maracana stadium.

item.title: The world's top 10 landmarks. Really?
item.description: Website users pick must-see sites ... with controversial choices.

item.title: How female pilot deals with sexism
item.description: Being a pilot is a tough dream job for many -- but Esther Mbabazi is also a pioneer.

item.title: Meet teen who looks like 'Frozen' star
item.description: Meet the Florida teenager who resembles Elsa, a character from the Disney animated film "Frozen." Affiliate WKMG reports.

item.title: Jimmy Choo tackles men's fashion
item.description: Max Foster looks at legendary shoe designer Jimmy Choo's expansion into men's fashion.

item.title: Hats off to British social season
item.description: The biggest sporting event on the globe may be taking place in Brazil at the World Cup, but try telling that to Royal Ascot.

item.title: Can London compete with Silicon Valley?
item.description: London's inaugural Technology Week is underway, as the United Kingdom's capital promotes its tech stars and shows it can compete with Silicon Valley. Here are five companies to watch, as they pitch to make it big.

item.title: How to buy 1 million air miles for $6,500
item.description: An entrepreneur is 150,000 miles into a scheme to earn 1 million air miles -- and it's only going to cost him the price of a few gift cards.

item.title: Boy finds mummified body in house
item.description: A 12-year-old boy exploring an abandoned house found a gruesome surprise in one of the closets. Affiliate WHIO reports.

item.title: Can Amazon help 3-D finally catch on?
item.description: Over its extensive history, 3-D entertainment has seen its share of successes and failures.

item.title: Clinton answers your questions
item.description: From Iraq and Libya to gun laws, Hilary Clinton answers your questions.

item.title: Rockets, dinosaurs: World's top museums
item.description: A woman with a mysterious smile is one of the most magnetic draws at the world's most popular museum.

item.title: Uber: Can taxi biz be worth $18B?
item.description: In the blink of an eye, Uber has emerged as one of the most esteemed companies in the United States, soaring in recent days to a market value of $18.2 billion. That's bigger than Hertz and Avis combined. But is the Uber story really as good as it seems?

item.title: Virtual reality: Next gaming frontier
item.description: In recent years, the gaming industry has seen a number of hyped trends come and go: games on social networks, 3-D gaming, systems that let you control in-game avatars by moving your body.

item.title: 6 (almost) forgotten colonial holdouts
item.description: Home away from home -- what can be found in the world's few remaining colonial outposts.

item.title: Pilot forced to jump from damaged plane
item.description: Brooke Baldwin and Chad Myers talk to Shawn Kinmartin about how he was able to survive jumping out of his damaged plane.

item.title: Europe's best new boutique hotels
item.description: A former fire station and a converted girls' school are among the elegant and quirky places celebrating their first summer.

item.title: What a shot! Amazing sports pics
Always him? Team of Balotellis
item.description: "We all dream of a team of Carraghers" is a tribute to Liverpool FC's former defender and cult hero, Jamie Carragher, which dares to hope for a first 11 made up entirely of the club's legend.

item.title: Persieing: World Cup craze
item.description: Forget planking, it's time to get "Persieing."

item.title: Men catch joyride on whale shark
item.description: Florida boaters catch a ride of a lifetime with a very large fish. WTSP's Isabel Mascarenas has the story.

item.title: Growing pains: How child stars grow up
Victim, shooter's fathers meet
item.description: One man is grieving his dead son -- killed by the other man's son.

item.title: Chinese 'pork' artist arrives in Sydney
item.description: Prominent Chinese-Australian artist Guo Jian has arrived in Sydney after being deported from China where he was held by police for 15 days following his comments on the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square military crackdown.

item.title: Immigration odyssey of Honduran kids
item.description: Tossed in a truck, robbed. Dumped at a house. Held for ransom.

item.title: Prince George learns to walk
item.description: Prince George takes his first public steps with his mom, Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge.

item.title: Jihad threat from ISIS 'Foreign Legion'
item.description: ISIS battalions fighting in Iraq and Syria include jihadists who have traveled from Europe -- but what happens when they come home? Will they bring terrorism with them?

item.title: Cat-ching! Cat cafes take over world
item.description: How adding cats to coffee and cookies became a hugely successful global trend.

item.title: The business of dating a soccer star
item.description: Away from the pitch, tabloids are hungry for photos of players' wives and girlfriends.

item.title: U.S.-Iran: Sworn enemies to partners?
item.description: The U.S and Iran, sworn enemies for 35 years, are talking about working together to quell the al Qaeda-inspired insurgency sweeping northern Iraq. How can it work?

item.title: Hero keeper stops Brazil
item.description: Mexico's brilliant goalie keeps Brazil at bay time and time again.

item.title: U.S. to Iraq?
item.description: As the Islamic militants advance in Iraq, the Pentagon moves more fire- and manpower into the region to prepare for whatever President Obama orders.

item.title: Soccer star dating
item.description: Eye-popping physiques, huge incomes, celebrity status -- and that's just the women.

item.title: Sewol defence
item.description: The lawyer for the first mate of the ill-fated Sewol ferry told an emotionally-charged court his client left the sinking ship because he thought the coast guard would be able to rescue the passengers.

item.title: New tech giants?
item.description: London's inaugural Technology Week is underway, as the United Kingdom's capital promotes its tech stars and shows it can compete with Silicon Valley. Here are five companies to watch, as they pitch to make it big.

item.title: Boutique hotels
item.description: A former fire station and a converted girls' school are among the elegant and quirky places celebrating their first summer.

item.title: Google's car is the 'future'
item.description: Google unveiled a self-driving car that doesn't have a steering wheel or pedals. Richard Quest reports.

item.title: Are old cellphones a new fad?
item.description: Vintage phones are back in style. Would you trade your smart phone in for fashion? CNN's Max Foster reports.

item.title: Go inside Brazil's war on drugs
item.description: Brazil cracks down on drug gangs in time for the World Cup, but is it enough? CNN's Shasta Darlington reports.

item.title: Mastering cyber-espionage
item.description: Hackers in Iran used social media to target American and Israeli officials in an elaborate cyber-spying scheme.

item.title: Man catches baby after fall
item.description: A vendor in China catches a baby who fell from two floors up.

item.title: Russian proton rocket fails
item.description: A Russian space rocket launch went sour Friday, destroying the booster and its payload, Russian state media said.

item.title: Meet India's next PM
item.description: India's prime minister in waiting is business friendly but controversial. CNN's Mallika Kapur reports.

item.title: What are 'firenadoes'?
item.description: Unruly wildfires and "devil winds" keep barreling across Southern California, destroying homes and spawning "firenadoes."

item.title: The world's best national parks
item.description: From biking hundreds of miles in Patagonia to trekking across Myanmar, iReporter Anne Dirkse has set foot on all seven continents, and she's done it all on her own. The travel writer and photographer from Loveland, Colorado, spends months out of the year uncovering hidden gems in other countries, and says some of her favorite places to visit are national parks.

item.title: 25 things we love about Poland
item.description: It's the land of Pope John Paul II, Frederic Chopin and really good cheese.

item.title: 53 spectacular wildlife photos
item.description: Camping in the freezing snow at an altitude of 6,000 feet. Trekking through the jungle with an armed guard. Sitting on a boat in crocodile-infested waters.

item.title: Meteors streak through night sky
item.description: So after all the hype, was the lost sleep and the sore necks from looking at the sky worth it?

item.title: You're never too young to be CEO
item.description: Lily Warren was just 8 years old when she decided to start her own business with her younger sisters.

item.title: Rise of 'cult' Eastern Lightning
item.description: The group was approaching fellow diners at a McDonald's restaurant in an eastern Chinese city on a recent Wednesday night, asking for their cellphone numbers, when one woman refused.

item.title: Tiananmen vigil in Hong Kong
item.description: CNN's Wilfred Chan attended a memorial service for the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre held in Hong Kong.

item.title: The killings China 'forgot'
item.description: Wang Jingyao creaks open a metal door to let us into his cramped apartment.

item.title: Activists: Where are they now?
item.description: To commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown in Beijing, CNN spoke to several key pro-democracy dissidents, some of whom were among the thousands of student protesters that fateful day on June 4, 1989.

item.title: How to win China's tourists
item.description: As the global travel industry rolls out the welcome mat for China's surge of outbound tourists, it should consider tipping the scales in their customers' favor.

item.title: Extremists busted in Xinjiang
item.description: Police in northwest China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region have busted 23 "terror and religious extremism groups and caught over 200 suspects," state news agency Xinhua reported, citing the regional public security department.
